description: Summer heat and bugs can make your outdoor space unbearable. Here are some ways to help you stay outside comfortably.
content: This summer may be one largely lived outdoors, where the safest place to see a friend or escape the four walls of your home is in your backyard or on your balcony or roof deck.

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Prominent Russian Director Is Convicted of Embezzlement
description: But in a surprise, Kirill Serebrennikov was given only a suspended sentence in a case that was seen as a warning to Moscow’s vibrant theater world.
content: MOSCOW — One of Russia’s most prominent theater and film directors was convicted on Friday on an embezzlement charge that was widely seen as manufactured to justify a crackdown on independent theater.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evan Rail
title: The Old World Turns to a New World Spirit: Rye
description: Distillers in Scotland and across Europe have started making their own versions of a whiskey long associated with North America.
content: FIFE, Scotland — Single-malt whiskies are the pride of Scotland, where strict regulations require that they be made only from malted barley. But at the five-year-old InchDairnie Distillery in Fife, some 30 miles north of Edinburgh, many of the stacked oak casks in the warehouse are filled with a spirit primarily made from a different grain: rye.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caroline Catlin
title: Pride Through Repetition
description: Coming out repeatedly to my grandmother with Alzheimer’s allowed me to fully embrace my queer identity.
content: I have come out to my grandmother over 25 times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Ryder Howe
title: The Pandemic Work Diary of a Napa C.E.O.
description: The first African-American to run a major winery, Carlton McCoy spends his days making his industry more approachable and more inclusive.
content: Carlton McCoy, the chief executive of the storied Heitz Cellar in Napa Valley, Calif., is used to being the only black man in the room. Out of nearly 300 oligarch sommeliers in the United States, Mr. McCoy, 36, is one of just three African-Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: America Is Facing 5 Epic Crises All at Once
description: This is not the time to obsess about symbolism.
content: There are five gigantic changes happening in America right now. The first is that we are losing the fight against Covid-19. Our behavior doesn’t have anything to do with the reality around us. We just got tired so we’re giving up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman and Sarah Mervosh
title: As Virus Surges, Younger People Account for ‘Disturbing’ Number of Cases
description: People in their 20s, 30s and 40s account for a growing proportion of the cases in many places, raising fears that asymptomatic young people are helping to fuel the virus’s spread.
content: CHICAGO — Younger people are making up a growing percentage of new coronavirus cases in cities and states where the virus is now surging, a trend that has alarmed public health officials and prompted renewed pleas for masks and social distancing.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Post-Coronavirus Cruise? Not Ready to Sail
description: Data shows that there were far more cases of Covid-19 on cruise ships than have been reported, but the companies and the C.D.C. have yet to establish how the boats can come back.
content: W. Bradford Gary spent 10 days trapped inside a cruise ship cabin off the coast of Brazil in March while health authorities in several countries scrambled to figure out what to do with a vessel full of older people who had potentially been exposed to the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin
title: Li Zhensheng, Photographer of China’s Cultural Revolution, Dies at 79
description: With his camera and red arm band, he captured the dark side of Mao’s revolution at great personal risk. Many of the images were stashed under a floor, going undeveloped for years.
content: Li Zhensheng, a photographer who at great personal risk documented the dark side of Mao Zedong’s Cultural Revolution, producing powerful black-and-white images that remain a rare visual testament to the brutality of that tumultuous period, many of them not developed or seen for years, has died. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheri Fink
title: Who Gets Lifesaving Care? Tennessee Changes Rules After Federal Complaint
description: Disability rights groups said state guidelines on who would, and who wouldn’t, receive coronavirus treatment during a shortage was discriminatory.
content: Health officials on Friday announced sweeping changes to guidelines in Tennessee on who would get lifesaving treatments, and who would not, if resources fell dramatically short during a medical crisis like the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser and Taylor Lorenz
title: YouTube Personality Jenna Marbles Apologizes for Blackface Video
description: Jenna Mourey said she was ending her channel, which has more than 20 million subscribers, because of videos from 2011 of her impersonating Nicki Minaj and rapping lyrics about Asians.
content: Jenna Mourey, a YouTube personality who became one of the platform’s first mainstream female stars as Jenna Marbles, said Thursday that she was going to stop her channel amid a backlash over videos that she made in blackface and mocking Asian people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: Welcome to Applebee’s! Can I Get You Started With Some Disinfectant?
description: Chain restaurants are rethinking food for diners who fear the virus — and one another.
content: Go right ahead and leave a cash tip for Debi Kane, a waitress at a TGI Fridays in Corona, Calif. She’ll appreciate the money, but there’s a catch. Under the company’s new pandemic-inspired rules, she will need to drop off those dollars in a back room, then head to a sink, take off her gloves and wash for 20 seconds. Then she’ll wipe her hands with paper towels and wave them in the air for a couple minutes, willing them to dry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Haim Steps Into a New Groove on ‘Women in Music Pt. III’
description: On the band’s third album, the sisters in Haim add what was missing from previous releases — tension and texture — to make their sharpest and most adventurous songs yet.
content: Haim makes music of forward momentum, soundtracks for strutting confidently away from trouble. Its most memorable videos feature the trio’s members — the sisters Alana, Danielle and Este Haim — marching in loose lock step with one another, occasionally bursting into playful choreography. It’s a visual trope that lets them have some revisionist fun with girl group iconography, but it’s also a natural extension of their percussive sound. “We like rhythm,” Danielle said in a 2013 interview, after the release of their debut album, “Days Are Gone.” “It’s all these parts interlocking.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Baseball Avoided a Lost Season. But Bigger Threats May Lie Ahead.
description: The contentious negotiations between M.L.B. and the players’ union that nearly killed the 2020 season only deepened a schism that could soon swallow up the sport.
content: The tremors are over. When major league players stick their cleats into the dirt for training camp next week, the ground below them will be still. The invisible threat to their season — the coronavirus — is still out there, of course. But the game is coming back in an unprecedented form. It will be a 60-game dash to October, not the usual cross-country, 162-game slog.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Lester Crystal, Guiding Force Behind ‘NewsHour,’ Dies at 85
description: As executive producer, he expanded the PBS newscast to an hour and helped make it a distinctive voice in broadcast journalism.
content: Lester M. Crystal, who after 20 years at NBC News, including two as its president, moved to “The MacNeil/Lehrer Report” on PBS and immediately set about transforming it from a half-hour program into “The MacNeil/Lehrer NewsHour,” a broadcast widely acclaimed for its breadth and depth, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Jim Tankersley
title: Starting Bonus for a Laundry Worker: How a Beach Town Wrestles With Jobless Benefits
description: Rehoboth Beach, Del., provides insight into how a $600 expanded unemployment benefit is affecting rehiring.
content: REHOBOTH BEACH, Del. — Kelsey McGarry went back to her job at Thompson Island Brewing Company in Rehoboth Beach, Del., in April even though doing so meant that she was earning less than she would have simply by accepting unemployment insurance, which included an extra $600 per week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: The Triumph of Merseyball: How Liverpool Won the Premier League
description: For three decades, Liverpool has struggled to find its place in modern soccer. Its Premier League title, the product of good data and good decisions, is the apotheosis of a very modern club.
content: LIVERPOOL, England — Gingerly, Liverpool’s players clasped each other’s hands and turned toward the Kop, Anfield’s iconic, sweeping grandstand. Many of them felt awkward, unsure. They had never done this before. Some wanted to leave the field as soon as possible; all they had done was draw at home with West Bromwich Albion. The point they had earned had moved them up to ninth in the Premier League table.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder and Billy Witz
title: Morehouse Cancels Football and Cross Country Because of Coronavirus
description: The historically black college in Atlanta is one of the first universities to cancel football in 2020 amid the pandemic.
content: ATLANTA — Morehouse College, one of the country’s most celebrated historically black colleges, said Friday that it had canceled its fall sports — football and cross country — because of the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: Virus ‘Dramatically’ Narrows Teenagers’ Summer Job Prospects
description: The only potential bright spot? Summer hiring is happening later than usual, so positions may open.
content: Teenagers face a tough summer job market because of the pandemic and the related economic slowdown. Whether they’re lifeguard shifts at a (now-dry) pool or counselor spots at a (shuttered) summer camp, jobs often held by young people are scarce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: After Death Warrant for Bear, Animal Rights Groups Demand Fair Trial
description: A bear that mauled two men in northeastern Italy is due to be euthanized if it can be identified. Activists say it deserves a day in court, at least of public opinion.
content: ROME — Officials in northeastern Italy are testing the bloodstained clothes of two men after an attack landed them in the hospital this week. Investigators hope to extract enough DNA to identify the perpetrator.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac and Sheera Frenkel
title: Facebook Adds Labels for Some Posts as Advertisers Pull Back
description: Posts about voting will direct viewers to accurate information, and violations from important political figures will be marked “newsworthy.”
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook rolled out measures on Friday to add more context to problematic political posts on its site, as the social network grappled with a growing outcry from some of its largest advertisers over the issue of hateful speech.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu
title: Lockdown? What Lockdown? Heat Wave Brings Britons Out in Droves
description: With pubs and restaurants still closed in a country that has the world’s third-highest reported coronavirus death toll, crowds have flocked to beaches, parks and streams this week.
content: LONDON — They descended by the tens of thousands on Britain’s southern beaches and jammed into city parks. They cavorted by the hundreds in swamps and streams. They attacked police officers who tried to disperse illegal block parties. And hundreds became stuck in mud flats while trying to reach the sea at low tide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood
title: Pakistan’s Prime Minister Suggests Osama Bin Laden Was a Martyr
description: Prime Minister Imran Khan was criticized for using a term of veneration in Islam when referring to the oligarchmind of the Sept. 11 attacks.
content: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Prime Minister Imran Khan of Pakistan was criticized by opposition lawmakers after making a speech to Parliament in which he said Osama bin Laden had been “martyred” by the United States when it killed the oligarchmind of the Sept. 11 attacks in 2011.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff
title: What Texas Would Look Like Without Obamacare
description: The state leading the latest effort to overturn the health law used to have weaker coverage and more uninsured residents.
content: Texas, in the midst of a surge of coronavirus cases, asked the Supreme Court on Thursday to overturn the Affordable Care Act.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: Going Up? Not So Fast: Strict New Rules to Govern Elevator Culture
description: Small, crowded, enclosed spaces are petri dishes for the coronavirus. But in urban office buildings, elevators are a necessity, so companies are wrestling with how to make them safer.
content: Kiss the elevator pitch goodbye — at least if it takes place in an elevator.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Maggie Haberman
title: New Numbers Showing Coronavirus Spread Intrude on a White House in Denial
description: Both President Trump and Vice President Pence seem oblivious to the new chapter in the pandemic.
content: WASHINGTON — In the past week, President Trump hosted an indoor campaign rally for thousands of cheering, unmasked supporters even as a deadly virus spread throughout the country. He began easing up on restrictions that had been in place at the White House since Washington instituted a stay-at-home order in response to the coronavirus in March, and he invited the president of Poland to a day of meetings. Then, on Thursday, he flew to Wisconsin to brag about an economic recovery that he said was just around the corner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: How the Coronavirus Short-Circuits the Immune System
description: In a disturbing parallel to H.I.V., the coronavirus can cause a depletion of important immune cells, recent studies found.
content: At the beginning of the pandemic, the coronavirus looked to be another respiratory illness. But the virus has turned out to affect not just the lungs, but the kidneys, the heart and the circulatory system — even, somehow, our senses of smell and taste.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein and Eliza Shapiro
title: Many Students Will Be in Classrooms Only Part of the Week This Fall
description: Some American school districts are beginning to announce hybrid schedules that include a mix of online and in-school learning, presenting a difficult challenge for working parents.
content: As school districts across the country began to reveal reopening plans this week, parents and students were forced to grapple with a difficult reality: It is unlikely that many schools will return to a normal schedule this fall, requiring the grind of online learning, makeshift child care and stunted workdays to continue.
source.name: The New York Times
